Hollow ball of cells after five days of fertilisation (just before implantation of the embryo).

Blood is a fluid comprising red blood cells, several types of white blood cells and small fragments of blood cells called platelets, which are involved in the blood clotting process. These cells are all suspended in yellowish or straw-coloured liquid called plasma.

Body Mass Index or the relationship between weight and height. Your BMI is defined by your weight in kilograms divided by your height in metres and the result is divided again by your height in metres.
Boiling is the process of applying heat to water until the temperature reaches about 100°C.

Also known as a sand box. It is a term used in construction and civil engineering. It describes an area where material (usually soil, gravel or sand) has been dug for use at another location.Borrow-pits used to extract soil and stones for construction are very common in rural Ethiopia inside and outside villages.
Blood pressure (BP) refers to how hard the blood is 'pushing' on the walls of the major blood vessels as it is pumped around the body by the heart.
An RUTF (Ready to Use Therapeutic Food) wheat and oat biscuit.
Passageways that carry air into all parts of the lungs. They are branches of the bronchi.
The area of skull which extends from the anterior fontanel to the upper border of the eye.
The practise of organising stock all together in "bundles".
Damage, hurt or destroy by fire.
The accumulation of calcium salts in the body tissue, normally in the formation of the bone. E.g. Calcification of the skeleton
One of the most widely used modern methods of processing and preserving food. It involves the careful preparation of food packed into a sealed tin.
A tube or hollow needle that can be inserted into a vein, often for the delivery or removal of fluid or for the gathering of data.
Capillaries are the smallest blood vessels in the body, having an internal diameter hardly larger than the diameter of a single red blood cell.
A large swelling over the fetal skull in the area that was pressed against the cervix during labour and delivery.

Starchy foods such as Injera, bread, potatoes, rice and cereals.Carbohydrates are referred to as energy-giving foods. They provide energy in the form of calories that the body needs to be able to work, and to support other functions. Carbohydrates are needed in large amounts by the body. Indeed, up to 65% of our energy comes from carbohydrates.
Individuals who are infected, but who do not have clinical manifestations. Carriers and active cases can both transmit the infection to others.
An individual who has a particular disease.

Cataracts are changes in clarity (clouding) of the lens in the eye, which interferes with the passage of light into the eye. As the lens gets increasingly cloudy (opaque), less and less light can get through it.
A thin tube inserted into a body cavity to drain fluid, especially into the bladder to extract urine. The procedure is called catherisation.
A cavity is a space in the human body which contains different organs, fluids and other structures.
Cells are the tiny building blocks of living matter, which can only be seen through a microscope.
A census is a collection of information on everyone in a population.
The narrow neck at the upper end of the vagina.

A channel is the physical means or the media by which the message travels from a sender to a receiver. The channel used to communicate a health message influences what information can be conveyed and how.

Chemo' refers to medical drugs, and 'prophylaxis' means 'an action taken to prevent a disease'. Chemoprophylaxis refers to the drugs given to exposed and susceptible hosts to prevent them from developing an infection.
Treatment of disease by medicinal drugs and other chemical substances.
Chilling involves reducing food temperatures, but only to approximately -1ºC. Refrigerators for cold storage/chilling are normally used at 0ºC to +8ºC.
Chlamydia is also one of the most common Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs), and is caused by bacteria called Chlamydia trachomatis.
In pregnant women, darkening of the skin over the forehead, bridge of the nose, or cheekbones.

One of the most effective and widely used methods for disinfecting water and making it safe to drink. Whatever the level, it is important that the correct quantity of chlorine is added to remove all impurities.
Choice' is to decide freely whether to use contraception and, if so, which method.

Choking is defined as an obstruction of the upper part of the windpipe (trachea) resulting in an acute life-threatening emergency. A person whose airway is obstructed will quickly become unconscious and die due to suffocation (lack of oxygen), unless the obstruction is quickly removed.
An acute diarrhoeal disease that affects the intestines and can kill vulnerable patients within a few hours if they are not treated quickly.
Long-term of frequently recurring. A chronic diease is one that lasts a long time.

Arrange systematically in classes or groups. E.g. IMNCI classifications are action-oriented illness categories which enable a healthcare provider to determine if a child should be urgently referred to a health centre, or can be treated at home.
Refers to cleaning:  removing dirt, wastes or unwanted things from the surface of objects using detergents and necessary equipment.
A larger-than-expected number of cases with similar symptoms, but without clear evidence (at this time) that they are connected in any way.
Simultaenous infection of a single cell by two or more virus particles. A globally common coinfection involves tuberculosis and HIV.
The formation of particles in a liquid by adding chemicals.
The first milk a mother's breasts produce. It is yellowish in colour.  It is rich in nutrients for the baby and also has maternal antibodies which protect the newborn from infection.
A state of being at ease and content.
The transmission of information from one person to another, or from a source to a destination.
A group of people, based on common values and norms, who live within a geographically defined area and who share a common language, culture or values.
Each of the parts of which a thing is being composed (formed).
A mixture of plant and animal waste that is allowed to rot for use as a fertiliser. Hay, dead leaves, vegetable waste, animal droppings, and manure all make good compost.
Composting is a controlled process in which this type of waste is collected in an open pit or heap and is decomposed by natural biological processes.
An illnesss or abnormality.
The loss of heat. E.g. Newborns lose heat by conduction when placed on a cold table, or weighing scale.

To be assured that any personal information will remain confidential or private. It is the control of disclosure of personal health information and limiting access of these personal matters to others.
The state of being unclear in one's mind about something.
A very thing transparent membrane that lines the inside of the eyelids and covers the sclera (white part of the eye).
Dry, hard, difficult stools (bowel movements) that do not come often.

Items that are used within a short period of time, so they need to be regularly replaced. They include all the medicines, drugs, vitamin supplements and infusion fluids (for intravenous use) that you will be trained to give to your patients in specific circumstances.
A minor substance, material or agent that is unwanted in the environment and may or may not be harmful.
The presence of an infectious agent or harmful microorganisms  E.g. Food can be contaminated by unhygienic practices in storage, handling, and transportation.
To receive follow-up or continuous care for as long as needed.
A situation or condition when a particular medicine should not be taken (Many medicines are contraindicated in pregnancy).

Control is a basic managerial function involving setting standards, evaluating against standards and taking corrective action. It is the process of regulating service activities so that your performance conforms to expected standards and goals, and it ensures that the necessary corrective action is taken place.
The loss of heat from the newborn's skin to the surrounding air.  E.g. When the baby is exposed to cool surrounding air or to a draught from open doors and windows or a fan.
An uncontrolled fit. A sudden jerking of part or all of ther person's body, as in meningitis or epilepsy.
Working together efficiently.
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a progressive respiratory disease that makes it hard to breathe.
The thick transparent tissue over the front part of the eye, covering the white, black and coloured areas (iris and pupil).
The most commonly used prophylactic drug for HIV/AIDS. It is a wide-spectrum antibiotic that targets the pathogens causing the most common opportunistic infections.
A person-to-person, two-way communication during which you provide adequate information to help the person make an informed decision.

The transfer of harmful microorganisms between food items and food contact surfaces. Prepared food, utensils and surfaces may become contaminated by raw food products and microorganisms. These can be transferred from one food to another by using the same knife, cutting board or other utensils.
The presenting part of the baby's head remains visible between contractions; this indicates that the cervix is fully dilated.

Involves growing the bacteria in the laboratory; this test can only be ordered by a doctor or a clinician. E.g. Culturing of TB bacteria from a sputum sample in the laboratory is very expensive and takes several weeks to produce a result.
Eradication of the cause of the illness or the complete removal of the pathogen from the body.
Curing is a general term that covers all types of food preservation (salting, sugaring, and smoking foods).
A bluish discolouration of the lips and skin, which occurs when there is insufficient oxygen in the blood.
An abnormal, sac-like, liquid-filled growth developing in the body.
A jelly-like fluid enclosed within the cell membrane and the cell's internal sub-structures.

Before and after the baby has been born, decontaminate (remove germs) from all instruments with a 0.5% chlorine solution. First, soak them for 10 minutes, then wash with a soapy solution and lastly with clean water. You can use a small brush to scrub them clean. After decontamination make the instruments ster
An individual who fails to complete treatment within the maximally allowed period of time.
A condition in which the body loses more liquid than it takes in. This lack of water is especially dangerous in babies.
The process of removing head lice parasites from human hair. These methods include chemical treatments, natural products, combs, shaving, hot-air and silicone based lotions.
This condition is more common in older people and is characterised by memory problems and broader problems with thinking and understanding.

The scientific study of characteristics and dynamics pertaining to the human population. These characteristics include births, deaths, age, income, education and gender. Other relevant characteristics include occupation, family size, housing,
In your work as a health educator you will often find yourself giving a demonstration. This form of health education is based on learning through observation.
The process of removing oxygen from a reaction mixture or solvent.
A mental illness characterised by low mood (sad mood). A state of excessive sadness or hopelessness.
The term fetal descent is used to describe the progressive downward movement of the fetal presenting part (commonly the head) through the pelvis.
The process of removing sludge from the septic tanks.
The process of giving an anthalmintic drug (wormer or dewormer) to get rid of parasites/worms.
Persons with diabetes have too much sugar in their blood.
A statement of the nature of a disease or other condition made after observing its signs and symptoms.
Contraceptive device of molded rubber or other soft plastic material fitted over the cervix to prevent entrance of spermatozoa.

Diarrhoea is the passage of loose faeces (liquid stool) three or more times a day, or more than is normal for the individual. If the diarrhoea continues for less than 14 days, it is referred to as acute diarrhoea; if it lasts for more than 14 days it is said to be chronic or persistent diarrhoea.
Diet is the sequence and balance of meals in a day. It is concerned with the eating patterns of individuals or a group.
To be treated with courtesy, consideration and attentiveness.
Disability is present when a person has a health condition (in this case, mental illness) which impairs their day-to-day functioning in some way.
A release or flowing out of fluid, mucus, or pus.
When a person is allowed to leave. E.g. the patient was discharged from the hospital
A discrepancy is a difference between what is reported and what is found.

Unfair treatment of a person in which a characteristic, e.g. mental illness, marks the person out as different and leads to negative attitudes (prejudice) and behaviour (discrimination) from other people. This stigma increases the burden of illness further.
A disturbance in the normal functioning of the body and is used interchangeably with illness.
The procedure of killing most, but not all, infectious agents outside the body by direct exposure to chemicals. Adding chlorine is one method of disinfecting water.
Conveying or delivering the message to each audience at a variety of different places.
Depot Medroxy Progesterone Acetate, or Depo-Provera is an artificial progestin preparation which resembles the naturally occurring female hormone progesterone. It is used as a contraceptive.
Of or on the back of an animal or plant.

Drug sensitivity testing (DST), performed in a reference laboratory. E.g.  It is the only means by which resistance to anti-TB drug(s) can be confirmed. DST involves growing TB bacteria and treating the culture with one or more anti-TB drugs and seeing if the bacteria are killed or not.
The time during which a thing continues.
A house etc. to live in.
The word dysentery refers to diarrhoea containing blood and mucus. It is usually caused by an infection.
Pain during menstruation.
Shortness of breath or breathlessness.
Pain on urination and pain during sexual intercourse.
Sudden fits, especially during pregnancy or childbirth.
An ecosystem includes all the living organisms (plants, animals, microorganisms), their physical environment and the interactions between them.
Expected date of delivery (EDD) and the gestational age of the fetus. Calculating the EDD and gestational age will help you to identify whether the labour is preterm, term or post-term.
A result. A change produced by an action or cause.
Producing an effect. Making a big impression.
The extent to which you have achieved your objectives with the available amount of resources.
In Public Health, elimination is reduction to zero (or a target very close to zero) of cases of a particular communicable disease in a particular geographic area.
Embryo: the developing human from fertilisation to the eighth week of pregnancy.
The hard white shiny substance which gives great strength to the tooth.
Essential newborn care (ENC) includes immediate care at birth, care during the first day and up to 28 days.
A disease of the brain.
Always present at a relatively constant rate. A communicable disease is said to be endemic in a region or country if it is always present there.

Endometritis is an infectious process involving the inner wall of the uterus (the endometrium). It is commonly caused by bacteria ascending from the vagina, or bacteria transferred to the reproductive tract from the rectum and anus.
The lining if the uterus.
Engagement is when the fetal head enters (i.e. the head is engaged) into the pelvic inlet.
Congestion with blood. Swelling of the breast.
Improve the quality by adding things. E.g. Enrich the food by adding some oil or butter.
Involuntary urination, either during the daytime or at night, and occurring at an age when complete bladder control is expected.

Within public health, the environment includes all those matters related to health which are external to the human body and over which the individual has little or no control. The environment includes all other factors that either promote or prohibit disease transmission.
Enzymes are chemical substances produced by cells in the body, which cause a particular chemical reaction to happen while not being changed themselves.

The Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI) began in 1974 when the World Health Assembly pledged to ensure that all children in all countries receive life-saving vaccines. Each year, immunization now prevents more than 2.5 million deaths among children worldwide.
An outbreak of disease affecting many persons in a community or region at the same time.
Epidemiology is the statistical study of the occurrence, distribution, potential causes and control of diseases, disabilities or other health problems in human populations.
A chronic or longstanding condition caused by abnormal electrical conductions in the brain.

Epilepsy is characterised by recurrent seizures (sometimes called fits). A seizure is caused by a sudden burst of excess electrical activity in the brain, causing a temporary disruption in the normal messages passing between brain cells. This disruption results in the brain's messages becom
(Plural: Epithelia). The tissue forming the outer layer of the body or of an open cavity.
The total and sustained disappearance of the disease from the population.
Errors (mistakes) can result from incorrect reading of the data, incorrect reporting, incorrect filing or incorrect typing.
Ethics is the branch of philosophy, which takes a systematic approach to define social and individual morality.

The ecosystem response to the addition of artificial or natural substances, mainly phosphates, through detergents, fertilizers, or sewage, to an aquatic system. E.g. a sudden increase in the population of microscopic algae. If a water body has high nutrient levels it is said to be eutrophic. The main problem of eutrophication is that the suddenly increased population of aquatic plants can die off equally quickly.

Evaluation is the systematic collection, analysis and reporting of information about health education activities. Evaluating means finding out how well you are doing in your health education work in your community, and making a judgment about your achievements.

Evaporation is the change from a liquid to a gas. When the sun shines on the surface of water, water molecules evaporate from the water body into the atmosphere.  Newborns lose heat by evaporation after delivery or after a bath.
Not included. A thing that does not follow the general rule.
An activity that requires physical or mental effort, done for the sake of health.
Expecting. Looking forward with hope or pleasure.
Expelling. E.g. Expulsion of baby's head.
The amount, degree, or range to which something extends or can extend. e.g. the act of straightening or extending a limb.
Emission. Discharge. A susbtance that is released or emitted.
Eyelashes are small hairs growing from the edges of the eyelids.

The eyelids are muscular folds of skin above and below your eyes that can open and close like a gate covering and revealing the eye. They protect the eye from foreign matter, such as dust, dirt and other debris that might damage the eyes.
The surface of the front of the head that extends from the upper ridge of the eye to the nose and chin (lower jaw).
Naturally oily substance, insoluble in water, found in animal bodies and certain seeds. E.g. butter and oil.
Able to be done, possible, likely. E.g. Consider the complexity of the problem and the resources you will require to carry out a study.

The mechanism of assessing what has happened to the receivers after the communication has occurred. A communication is said to have feedback when the receiver of the message gives his or her responses back to the sender of the message.
When storing and using drugs and other pharmaceutical supplies. FEFO: First-Expired, First-Out (first use the drug that will expire first).
Chemical changed caused by the action of an organic substance such as yeast, involving production of heat. E.g. when sugar is converted into alcohol.

In humans, fertilisation is defined as the fusion of the sperm nucleus with the ovum nucleus. For fertilisation to occur, sperm must be deposited in the vagina no earlier than three days before ovulation or within one day after ovulation.
The developing baby inside the womb.
A body temperature higher than normal.

A mixture of different carbohydrates which are not digested like other nutrients but pass through the gut nearly unchanged. Foods rich in fibre are 'kocho'; vegetables like cabbage, 'kosta', carrots, cassava; fruits like banana and avocado; peas and beans; whole-grain cereals.
When storing and using drugs and other pharmaceutical supplies. FIFO: First-In, First-Out (first use the drug that first went into the cupboard or refrigerator).

An abnormal opening (usually as a result of ruptured tissues) between either the vagina and the urinary bladderì, the recturm the urethra or the ureter.
A sudden, violent attack of a disease, causing convulsions or spasms and sometimes unconsciousness.

Fluoride is a substance found in nature that strengthens teeth and helps prevent tooth decay. Most water systems naturally contain some fluoride, but the amounts must be 'just right' to promote oral health. Not getting enough fluoride in the diet or water supply increases the risk of tooth decay.
A further action. E.g. A follow-up visit has a different purpose from an initial visit, to monitor the patient's treatment and health status.
Inanimate objects that carry the infectious agent (e.g. dishes, cups and other contaminated surfaces or objects) that can transmit infection from one person to another.

A fontanel or 'soft-spot' is the space created by the joining of two or more sutures. It is covered by thick membranes and the skin on the baby's head, protecting the brain underneath the fontanel from contact with the outside world.
Increasing the food value of certain food by adding vitamins.
A fracture is where there is a break in a bone caused by a force applied to the body. The degree of damage depends on the magnitude of force applied and the strength of the bone.
The condition of being free, independent.
The most commonly used type of freeze indicator is the freeze-tag. This is an irreversible temperature indicator that shows if a product, such as a vaccine, has been exposed to freezing.
The number of times that an event occurs within a specific period.
The rounded top of the uterus, between the junctions with the two fallopian tubes.
A standard scale of measurement. An instrument for measuring the dimensions, capacity, or amount of something.
Gender-based violence (GBV) is any form of deliberate physical, psychological or sexual harm, or threat of harm, directed against a person on the basis of their gender.
Gender refers to the socially and culturally defined roles for males and females.
Giardiasis is a faeco-oral disease which results from infection of the small intestine by protozoa called Giardia intestinalis, also known as Giardia duodenalis.

Glands are organs of the body which produce natural substances such as hormones and breast milk, and fluids that keep the body in fluid balance. Salivary glands are organs that produce saliva and release it into the mouth, particularly when we are hungry and when we are chewing food.

The action of the hormone glucagon works in the opposite direction to insulin. Glucagon causes the blood glucose level to rise if it has fallen too low. It does this by stimulating the liver, muscles and body fat to release their stored glucose back into the blood.
The simplest form of sugar. It is the principal circulating sugar in the blood of humans and other mammals.
A carbohydrate stored in the liver and muscles of animals that is converted to glucose for energy when glucose levels in the blood are depleted. It is also called animal starch.
A goal is the overall purpose of a project. It is a broad statement of what you are trying to do.
A swelling of the thyroid gland. Goitre is common as a result of too little iodine in the diet.

Gonorhoea is one of the most common Sexually Transmitted Infection and is caused by bacteria called Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It  affects  the  mucous  membrane  chiefly  of  the  genital  and  urinary  tracts  and  is  characterized  by  an  acute  purulent  discharge  and  painful  or  difficult  urination,  though  women  often  have  no  symptoms.
Gravidity is the total number of previous pregnancies, regardless of the outcome, including spontaneous miscarriage or abortion before 28 weeks of gestation.

Groundwater includes all water that is found underground within the rocks; some groundwater may be near the surface and some may be deep underground. Groundwater can be obtained from springs, boreholes, or wells.
Groups are gatherings of two or more people with a common interest; they are a good target for your health education sessions.
Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point system (HACCP)  can be applied at all stages in the production, processing and handling of food products.
Haemoglobin is the red, iron-rich protein that gives red blood cells their colour and enables them to pick up oxygen and transport it around the body.
Excessive blood loss.
Haemorrhoids (also known as piles) are swollen veins around the anus. They may burn, hurt, or itch. Sitting or standing a lot can make haemorrhoids worse.
The act of annoying/bothering/pestering/tormenting.
A shelter or refuge.
Home Education Activities Drugs Sexuality. The HEADS assessment tool is used to assess adolescents in areas of difficulty that may be indicative of social and psychological problems.

A burning feeling or pain in the stomach, or between the breasts, is called indigestion or heartburn. E.g. Heartburn happens because the growing baby crowds the mother's stomach and pushes it higher than usual.
The age that corresponds to the child's height when plotted at the 50th percentile on a growth chart.
The collective name given to parasitic worms. They have complicated lifecycles, and some helminths require transmission between humans and other host animals before they mature.

Medical condition defined by serious inflammation of the liver. Several viruses can cause hepatitis, but the hepatitis B virus (or HBV) is the most important one. Hepatitis B disease is a major global health problem and the most serious type of viral hepatitis.

Human Immunodeficiency Virus that causes the Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). HIV destroys the body's defences against other infections, which lead to death if the person is not treated appropriately with anti-HIV drugs. HIV is carried in the blood of an infected person and also appears in the genital tract of infected men and women.

Treating the whole person rather than just the symptoms of a disease. E.g. Taking into account all of the child's problems including the major childhood illnesses in the assessment and treatment of illness.

Hormones are signalling substances produced by collections of cells, called endocrine glands, which release their hormones into the blood. Different hormones control or regulate the activity of different cells.
The host is any susceptible organism that could be affected by a disease. Plants, animals or humans can be invaded by the infectious agent and become the host.
Hygiene generally refers to the set of practices associated with the preservation of health and healthy living.

High blood pressure. There are many causes of hypertension, including kidney diseases, narrowing of the aorta (the biggest artery leaving the heart), diabetes,the excessive use of alcohol and some medical drugs.
Very low blood sugar.
Excessive cooling of a person or reduction of body temperature which, if not prevented, may result in the body systems stopping their functions.
Acute shortage of oxygen in the blood.

Ice-packs are flat, rectangular plastic bottles filled with water and then either kept at refrigerator temperature, or frozen and then conditioned for use in vaccine carriers and cold boxes. The number of ice-packs required for a cold box or vaccine carrier varies.
Determine, place, know.
Not legally permitted or authorized. Illicit substances are those which are prohibited by law.
Unhealthy condition, poor health, sickness.
An immune-competent person is an individual whose immune system is healthy and functions normally.
The resistance of an individual to communicable diseases caused by infectious agents. The main types of infectious agents are bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa and parasites
Medicines that give protection against specific diseases, for example, diptheria, whooping cough, tetanus, polio, tuberculosis and measles.
Causing or capable of producing immunity.

Integrated Management of Newborn and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) is an integrated approach to child health that focuses on the wellbeing of the whole child. It is a strategy that integrates all available measures for health promotion, prevention and integrated management of childhood diseases through their early detection and effective treatment, and promotion of healthy habits within the family and community.

An impact is an immediate effect or change produced by an intervention. In health education, these immediate changes may include changes in awareness, knowledge, attitudes, beliefs, skills or health-related behaviours. Impact evaluation refers to assessing the immediate effects of your health education campaign/program.
The state of being diminished, weakened, or damaged, especially mentally or physically. E.g. visual impairment is a decreased ability to see.

A single-rod contraceptive implant prepared from another type of progestin, which gives effective protection for three years. It looks like a small flexible plastic matchstick. It can be inserted into the arm following a simple procedure, similar to an injection.
In human fertilisation, implantation occurs when the blastocyst reaches the uterus and embeds itself in the thickened endometrium (lining of the uterus).
To carry out. The act of converting your planning, goals, objectives and strategies into action.
Implying, implicating. Suggest without stating directly, hint.
Of much or great significance or value.
Sexual activity between two people who are considered, for moral or genetic reasons, too closely related to have such a relationship.
Occurence. Incidence of disease refers to the number of new cases of a disease occurring in a given period. It conveys information about the risk of contracting the disease.

To burn. In waste management terms, incineration means burning in a controlled and managed process usually at high temperature.Incineration is a good way of disposing of waste, because it completely destroys needles, syringes, glass vials, and infectious agents by burning at very high temperatures.
The act of including. Involving someone or something to be part of a whole.
Unable to control urine.

Device or instrument that records changes, indicating the condition of something/someone. In monitoring child growth, an indicator is an index (for example, a scale showing weight for age, or weight for height) combined with specific cut-off values that help you determine whether a child is underweight or malnourished; for example, a child whose weight for age, or weight for height, falls below the cut-off values. In health education, indicators are used to measure changes related to intervention.
Baby or young child aged less than one year.
A sickness caused by bacteria or other germs. Infections may affect part of the body only or all of it.
Below. Lower in place or position. Less important.
The inability to conceive a child after having unprotected sexual intercourse for a period of at least one year.
An area that is red, hot, and painful often because of infection.
First. E.g. first visit or initial visit.
The first individuals to adopt an innovation.

Not having the structure or organization characteristic of living bodies. Foodstuffs are of two main kinds: organic (carbohydrate, proteins, fats) and inorganic (water, various mineral elements and vitamins).
A poison that kills insects. E.g. Insecticides are used to kill mosquitoes and protect communities from mosquito bites.
A condition in which a person is not able to sleep, even though he wants and needs to.

Insulin has many functions, but its main role is to help glucose enter into the body's cells, so they can use it as a fuel for all the processes that need energy. The pancreas releases insulin into the blood when we eat a meal.
Great energy, strength, concentration of an activity, thought or feeling.
An intervention for the disease that targets the source, environment or the host. An intervention is a way of stopping the disease from being transmitted.

Interviewing involves oral questioning of respondents, either individually or as a group. This is a face-to-face or personal interview method and requires a person, the interviewer, asking questions to the other person, the respondent.
Within or between the layers of the skin. The vaccine is injected into the top layers of the skin.
Within the muscle. The vaccine is injected into the muscle, usually of the arm or the buttock.
Within the vein. Infusion of liquid substances directly into a vein.
The iris is the coloured part of your eye around the pupil.
The ischium is the thick lower part of the pelvis, formed from two fused bones, one on either side.
The complete seperation from others of a person with a contagious or infectious disease. It is important to isolate people with highly severe and easily transmitted diseases.
Insecticide Treated Nets are mosquito nets impregnated with insecticide that repel, disable or kills mosquitoes coming into contact with it.

Intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) or an intrauterine device (IUD). It is an effective, safe, long-acting, cost-effective contraceptive method. It consists of a plastic or metal object that a specially trained health worker or midwife places inside the womb.
Jadelle is a progesterone-only contraceptive implant consisting of two rods implanted (instead of 6 rods in Norplant) to give effective protection for five years.
A yellow colour of the eyes and skin. It is a sign of disease in the liver, gallbladder, pancreas or blood.
Justice is a complex ethical principle and it entails fairness, equality and impartiality; in other words, it is the obligation to be fair to all people.

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC), called after the way that kangaroos look after their young, has been shown to be an extremely effective method of caring for preterm and low birth weight babies. It involves holding a newborn in skin-to-skin contact, day and night, prone and upright on the chest.

The collection and storage of information and experience. Good quality health education relies on the provision of correct, credible, simple and understandable facts and information. Providing knowledge is about helping someone who has a problem, in the case of your job a health problem, so you will have to be aware of the possible health problems, their consequences and ways of preventing them.
Severe form of acute malnutrition characterised by swollen feet, hands and face, and peeling sores. It is caused by not eating enough protein.
The production of colostrum and then milk by the breasts, and the release of these nutritious fluids when the baby suckles the mother's nipple.
The use of chemicals or biological agents or toxins to kill mosquito larvae. Water collections that cannot be managed by environmental control measures can be dealt with by larvicides.
Away from the midline (sides, edges).

In landfill sites and some community waste disposal sites, the solid waste decomposition process will produce leachate. Leachate is formed when the liquid fraction from a mixed solid waste is separated by gravity from the solid component.

Leading is the management function that you will use when influencing, motivating and directing people in your team towards the achievement of your organisational goals. All teams benefit from direction and as a leader you must deal with and motivate the people you work with in your health teams.

A chronic parasitic disease, which exists in two forms: visceral leishmaniasis (also known as kala-azar), which affects the internal organs such as the liver and spleen, and cutaneous leishmaniasis, which affects the skin.
Extent in time, duration. E.g. For women in labor, length refers to the amount of time each contraction lasts. Measure the time on your watch (if you have one).
The lens of the eye is a clear flexible structure that is located just behind the iris and the pupil. The lens focuses the light as it passes through the eye onto the retina at the back of the eye.
Legal, lawful. Licit substances: those which are not regulated or prohibited.
The medical term for the amniotic fluid; if the fetal membranes have ruptured.

Long-lasting insecticidal nets. LLINs are nets treated in the factory with an insecticide incorporated into the net fabric which makes the insecticide last at least 20 washes in standard laboratory testing and three years of recommended use under field conditions. With LLINs therefore the time consuming method of retreating old nets is no longer necessary.
First day of the woman's Last Normal Menstrual Period (LNMP). It is used to calculated the expected date of delivery.

In health promotion, one of the advocacy tools you will use is lobbying, which means influencing the policy process by working closely with key individuals in political and governmental structures, together with other decicion makers at local level.
The liquid discharge from the uterus that appears after childbirth.
When body lice are found, for example in clothes, the articles are said to be louse-infested.
Lower respiratory tract infections (LRIs) are the leading cause of pneumonia and bronchitis.

Latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). Up to one-third of the world's population is thought to be infected with latent TB. A person with latent TB idoes not develop active TB or become ill at the time. LTBI is not contagious.

The most important group of white blood cells in our defence against infection. There are several types of lymphocytes. E.g. Lymphocytes called B cells are responsible for producing special proteins called antibodies.
Skin lesions which mwhich are flat.

An infection of the blood that causes chills and high fever. Malaria is spread by mosquitos. The mosquito sucks up the malaria parasites in the blood of an infected person and injects them into the next person it bites.
Health problems caused by not eating enough of the foods that the body needs.
Malpresentation is any presentation other than vertex (the top of the baby's skull is the presenting part). The most common malpresentations are breech.

Management is quite simply getting things done through people. As a Health Extension Practitioner at community level, your job will involve management because it will help you achieve your intended goals. Using management techniques will help show you how to make changes to improve the health of everyone in your community.
A form of severe mental illness in which a person is excessively happy or irritable (experiences extreme mood swings), and appears over-active.
A mixed form of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. It is characterized by the presence of both wasting and bilateral pitting oedema.
A form of severe malnutrition. A child has marasmus if he is very thin, has reduced subcutaneous fat, and looks like skin and bones. Some children are thin but do not have visible severe wasting.
Painful inflammation of the breast due to bacterial infection; usually in the first weeks or months of nursing a baby. It causes part of the breast to become hot, red, and swollen.
A deep infection in the mastoid bone. The mastoid bone, which sits behind the ear, consists of air spaces that help drain the middle ear.
Community-directed mass drug administration (MDA).
Throughout the world, there are almost 30,000 cases of multidrug resistant-TB (MDR-TB), a form of TB that does not respond to the standard treatments using the drugs most commonly used against TB.
The average of a series of measurements or scores. To calculate the mean, you add up all the individual measurements or scores and then divide this by how many numbers there are.

Measles is a highly transmissible infectious disease caused by the measles virus. Most cases occur in children aged between six months and two years.Initial signs and symptoms typically include fever, often greater than 40 °C, cough, runny nose, and red eyes.Two or three days after the start of symptoms small white spots may form inside the mouth. A red flat rash typically begins three to five days after the first symptoms.
The baby's first stool (greenish-black in colour).
Towards the midline of the body.
A measure of central location, where half of the measures are below and the other half are above this value.
Menstruation. Monthly bleeding in women.
The time when a woman naturally stops having monthly bleeding, usually between the ages of 40 and 50.
A piece of information that contains a combination of ideas, facts, opinions, feelings or attitudes. A message is something that is considered important for the audience to know or do.
The process by which food is built up into living material or used to supply energy in a living organism.
A tiny plant or animal so small it can only be seen with the aid of a microscope.
The most common man-made structures in Ethiopia, used to harvest rain water for horticulture and small scale irrigation.
The science that deals with the study of microorganisms.
Minor lesions.

As their name indicates ('micro' means small) micronutrients are substances which people need in their diet in only small amounts. These include minerals and vitamins. Although most foods are mixtures of nutrients, many of them contain a lot of one nutrient and a little of the other nutrients.
A severe, throbbing headache, sometimes on one side of the head only. It often causes vomiting.
When any label, writing or other printed or graphic matter on a food container is false or misleading. Misbranding violates food safety regulations and is unlawful.
Spontaneous abortion. The death of the developing baby or fetus in the womb, sometimes followed by heavy bleeding with blood cots.
Simple metals or other things the body needs, such as iron, calcium or iodine.

The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) is defined as the number of maternal deaths in a given year, in a particular area (which can be a whole country, or a region, or a community such as your community), divided by the number of live births in the same year and area. The result is multiplied by 100,000 live births, so that comparisons can be made with other years and other areas.
The most common result (the most frequent value) of a test, survey or experiment.
A representation, to show the construction or appearance of something.
Changeable or controllable.

A process by which priority data and/or information is routinely collected, analysed, used and disseminated to see progress towards the achievement of planned targets. This helps the managers take timely corrective actions in order to improve performance.

A people's feeling state that varies depending on the events that happen around them. Sad events such as sickness or the death of a loved one produce a sad mood. Happy events, such as attending a wedding, induce a happy mood.
Goodness. Abiding to the rules of right conduct.
Death.
Solid ball of cells after three days of human embryo fertilisation.
The extent of overlapping of fetal skull bones as the baby's head is forced down the birth canal. It can produce a pointed or flattened shape to the baby’s head when it is born.
A thick, slippery liquid that moistens and protects the linings of the nose, throat, stomach, guts and vagina.
A pregnant woman who has been pregnant two or more times.
A woman who has previously given birth to live babies at least twice before now.
Manual vacuum aspiration or MVA (Medical abortion): using an instrument like a syringe operated by hand that creates a negative pressure to suck out the contents of the uterus.
The muscle layer in the wall of the uterus.
Of or relating to the nose.
Stomach distress or upset; feeling like you need to vomit.
Newborn baby from birth to 28 days old.
Thin threads or strings that run from the brain to every part of the body and carry messages for feeling and movement.
Skin lesion.Small rounded mass or lump.
Non-adherence is the patient's inability to take their drugs correctly, or attend scheduled clinical visits in the prescribed manner as recommended by their healthcare providers.
Non-consumables are items of equipment that can be used for years, but may eventually have to be replaced or updated.
Non-changeable or non-controllable. E.g. Risk factors such as age, sex and inherited genes.
The concept of nonmaleficence tells you to 'do no harm' either intentionally or unintentionally to your clients, for instance, not abandoning a client who is in need of your service/help.
Noristerat (NET-EN or norethisterone enanthate) is another artificial progestin preparation which resembles the natural female hormone progesterone. It is intended for short term contraceptive use.
Usual, natural, or average. Something that is normal has nothing wrong with it.
The largest structure in any cell, which contains most of the DNA in the cell.
An active chemical component in food that plays a specific structural or functional role in the body's activity.
The process by which organisms take in and use food.
Nourishing. Nutritious foods are those that have things the body needs to grow, be healthy and fight off disease.
The intended impact or effect of the work you are doing, or the specific change that you want to see.
An act of noticing or perceiving.
A condition of being blocked or clogged. An obstructed gut is a medical emergency.

This is the most common malposition where the baby's head initially engages normally but then the occiput rotates posteriorly rather than anteriorly. A baby that presents in the occipito-posterior position may encounter more difficulties during delivery.
The point at the back of the fetal skull, which is lying in the anterior position, that is, towards the front of the mother's pelvis, where the two pubic bones are fused together.
Swelling due to collection of fluid in the tissues.
A salve or lotion to use on the skin.
A parasitic vector-borne disease caused by a worm that affects the skin, lymph nodes and the eyes of infected people. It is also called river blindness.
Of the eye.
By mouth. An oral medicine is one taken by mouth.
A part of the body that is more or less complete in itself and does a specific job. For example, the lungs are organs for breathing.
Arrange in an orderly or systematic way.
Living things (animals or plants).
Oral rehydration salts (ORS) are used to prevent or treat dehydration. It is a packet containing sugar and salts in the correct amounts, which the caregiver dissolves in clean drinking water.
Softening of the bones due to reduction in the concentration of calcium in the bone. This condition is more common in older persons.
A sudden breaking out or occurence e.g. of a disease/epidemic.
Small sacs in a woman's belly next to her womb. They produce the eggs that join with a man's sperm to make a baby.
To take more than the recommended dose of a drug.
The release of a mature ovum from the ovary.
The recommended uterotonic drug to induce labor and to control postnatal hemorrhage.
Percentage of children protected at birth (PAB) from neonatal tetanus, because their mother received a valid dose of TT2+ vaccination at least two weeks before delivery.
A rubber or plastic device, often shaped into a nipple, for a baby to suck or bite on. Also known as dummies.
Acceptable or agreeable to the palate or taste. Food should also be palatable or tasty and good to eat.
The roof or top part of the mouth.
Unusual or extreme paleness.
To examine by touch, especially for the purpose of diagnosing disease or illness.
Raised skin lesions.
Loss of the ability to move part or all of the body.
Worms and tiny animals that live in our on another animal or person and cause harm. Fleas, intestinal worms, and amebas are parasites.
Parasitological or parasite-based diagnosis is a process using specific tests to identify the presence of parasites or of its products in the blood.
Not by mouth but by injection.
A chart used to assess the progress of labour, and of fetal and maternal condition during labour.  It is the best tool to help you detect whether labour is progressing normally or abnormally.
Pasteurisation is a process of heat treatment of milk, beer and some other beverages to a certain temperature (60°C) for about 30 minutes in order to kill harmful bacteria.
Disease-causing E.g. pathogenic viruses, bacteria, protozoa and parasites.
Disease causing organisms.

The vaccine that is being introduced in Ethiopia as part of the EPI is called PCV10, also known by its brand name Synflorix. PCV10 is highly effective at preventing infections caused by the strains of Streptococcus pneumonia.
Hip bones.
A rate or proportion, per 100.
The act of becoming aware of, noticing.
The slow movement of water through the pores in soil or permeable rock.
To carry out, to act.
The thin lining between the guts and body wall. The bag that holds the guts.
A very dangerous inflammation of the peritoneum. The belly gets hard like a board, and the person is in great pain, especially when he tries to lie with his legs straight.
A measure of how acidic or alkaline an environment is, on a scale of 0 to 14, where less than 7 represents acidity, 7 neutrality, and more than 7 alkalinity.
Pharingitis generally begins with the sudden onset of fever (temperature above 37.5°C), and a sore throat, with redness and swelling of the tonsils at the back of the throat.
The study of the bodily functions of living organisms and their parts.
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), is an inflammation of the uterus and fallopian tubes due to bacterial infection or other pathogens.
Provider-initiated HIV testing and counselling (PITC). This means that when trained to do so, you should offer and provide HIV testing and counselling yourself.

The placenta is a temporary organ required for the development of the embryo and fetus. It allows for the exchange of nutrients and oxygen from mother to fetus, and the transfer of fetal waste products back to the mother for disposal by her organs. The placenta normally comes out 15 minutes to half an hour after the baby is born.

A condition in which the placenta is too low in the womb and blocks the mouth of the womb. The risk of dangerous bleeding is high. Women who have bleeding late in pregnancy- a possible sign of placenta previa- should go to hospital at once.

Planning is an important skill for Health Extension Practitioners because it is a key management function for all healthworkers and health managers. Planning is the process of determining in advance what should be accomplished and when, by whom, how and at what cost.
Malaria is an infection of the red blood cells caused by a parasite called plasmodium that is carried by certain kinds of mosquitoes.
Blood is a fluid comprising red blood cells, several types of white blood cells and small fragments of blood cells called platelets, which are involved in the blood clotting process.
People living with HIV. PLHIV refers to everyone who is infected with the HIV virus.
Lower respiratory tract infection that mainly affects the lungs. Pneumonia requires antibiotics for treatment.
A reaction in the body to very small soil particles that have passed through the skin of the feet. The swelling begins in the feet.

Poliomyelitis (Polio). A viral disease that causes paralysis (weakness or inability to use the muscles) of the legs, arms or hands. Polio is caused by three types of viruses, namely, poliovirus types 1, 2 or 3.
A contaminant which, due to its properties or amount or concentration, causes harm to human health, animals, plants and the wider environment.
A form of marriage in which a person marries more than one spouse.
A condition in which the pregnant woman has too much amniotic fluid. If the abdomen is either too big or too small, refer the mother to a health facility.
Young persons aged 20-24 years.
Behind, at the back of.
Strength or effectiveness E.g. of a vaccine.
Postpartum haemorrhage (or PPH) is defined as excessive bleeding from the reproductive tract at any time following the baby's birth and up to six weeks after delivery.
Pre-eclampsia is the commonest type of hypertensive disorder of pregnancy. It usually occurs in the second half of pregnancy (after 20 weeks of gestation, but most commonly after 28 weeks).
In health eductation, pre-testing is testing the message with representatives of your target audience before the message is disseminated to a wider audience.
Water falling from the atmosphere to the Earth's surface; mostly this means rain, although it also includes snow.
Negative attitudes from other people. An unfavorable opinion or feeling formed beforehand without knowledge, thought or reason.
The condition of being prevalent or widespread. E.g. The total number of cases of a particular disease or health condition existing in a population at a certain point in time.
Action taken to stop sickness before it starts.

Primacy, the state of being first, often creates a strong impression which may be very difficult to change. Things learned first create a strong impression in the mind that is difficult to erase. 'Unteaching' or erasing from the mind incorrect first impressions is harder than teaching them correctly.
First pregnancy.

The process of arranging the problems/activities/tasks in order of the urgency in which they need to be addressed. It is impossible to solve all problems at once because there are many resource constraints.
The state of being apart from other people, free from unwanted disturbance. E.g. It is important to have a private environment during counselling and services.
Progesterone is a hormone produced by the corpus luteum in the ovary; its function is to prepare the endometrium (lining of the uterus) for the reception and development of the embryo.
A movement towards a goal.
Pushing out of the proper place'. The slipping or falling down of a part of the body from its normal position; for example, a prolapsed rectum or womb.
Health promotion includes health education/counselling and health service dissemination.
Treatment aimed at prevention.

A proportion, sometimes called relative frequency, is simply the number of times the observation occurs in the data, divided by the total number of responses. Proportions are very often converted to percentage values because this makes comparison easier between different sets of data.
Commercial sex work.

Proteins are needed in our diets for growth (especially important for children, teens and pregnant women) and to improve immune functions. They also play an important role in making essential hormones and enzymes, in tissue repair, and preserving lean muscle mass. E.g. meat, fish, nuts, egg yolk and soya products.
The appearance of protein in the woman's urine. It is a danger sign.
Micro-organisms made up of one cell; for example, Plasmodium falciparum. Bacteria are also micro-organisms made up of one cell.

Confusion. Psychosis involves loss of contact with reality, usually with false beliefs about what is taking place or one's own identity (delusions), and seeing or hearing thinhs that aren't there, and have disturbed behaviour.
Pulmonary Tuberculosis (PTB) that affects the lungs (80% of TB cases are of this type).

The time in which sexual and physical characteristics mature. The exact age a child enters puberty depends on a number of different things, such as genes, nutrition and sex. Most girls and boys enter puberty between 10-16 years of age although some start earlier or later.
The postnatal period. It includes the normal processes of physical and psychological adjustments in the period of about six weeks after the birth.
Tooth pulp is the deepest part of the tooth structure, where nerves and blood vessels are found. If it becomes diseased or injured and can't repair itself, the tooth dies and will soon fall out.
The central opening in the ring-shaped muscular tissue of the iris. It gets smaller in bright light and larger in the dark.
A yellowish-white, sticky fluid formed in infected tissue, consisting of bacteria, white blood cells, cellular debris and dying tissue.
Pus-filled blisters usually seen around the umbilicus or in the nappy area.
A list of questions with a space under each one for the researcher to write the answers given by the respondent.

A defined number that must be included in a sample. Quota sampling is a method that ensures that a certain number of subjects from different subgroups with specific characteristics appear in the sample, so that all these characteristics are represented.
A severe life-threatening viral disease, transmitted to humans in saliva in the bite of infected animals, particularly those in the dog family (canines).
In a newborn, radiation is the loss of heat from a newborn's skin to distant cold objects, such as a cold window or wall etc.
Forced sexual intercourse.
For example, a situation in which a person already living with HIV is infected with a new strain of HIV from another PLHIV. Re-infection can accelerate progression to AIDS.
For example, the process of progression from LTBI to active TB is called reactivation. The greatest risk for developing active TB is within the first two years following the initial infection.

A degree of willingness and eagerness of an individual to learn something new. Individuals learn best when they are physically, mentally and emotionally ready to learn — and they do not learn well if they see no reason for learning.

The principle of recency states that things most recently learned are best remembered. Conversely, the further a learner is removed time-wise from a new fact or understanding, the more difficult it is to remember.
The process of mixing vaccines that come as powders with the diluent provided with the vaccine.

A process by which waste is processed in some way to be reformed into new or similar products. The principle is to make a usable product from the waste. Plastic bottles, newspapers, cardboard and tin cans can all be reprocessed and made into new items.
Keeping to a minimum.
Sending a client for additional health services and specialised care at a higher level health facility.

A cooling apparatus. Health facility refrigerators may be powered by electricity, kerosene, paraffin, bottled gas or solar energy. Electric refrigerators are usually the least costly to run and the easiest to maintain, but they must have a reliable electricity supply.
A defined course of drug treatment.
A drink to correct dehydration, which you can make with boiled water, salt, and sugar or powdered cereal.
A patient who has been declared cured or treatment completed in the past, but who reports back to the health service with the same initial symptoms of illness.
To make less tense, rigid or firm.

The collection, analysis and interpretation of data with the aim of answering certain questions or solving certain problems. Health research is aimed at investigating health-related problems systematically and using this knowledge to design better solutions for these problems.

In the context of the water cycle and hydrology, reservoir means all stores of water.  The place where the infectious agent is normally present before infecting a new human. Without reservoirs, infectious agents could not survive and hence could not be transmitted to other people.
The ability of something to defend itself against something that would normally harm or kill it. Many bacteria become resistant to the effects of certain antibiotics.
What is needed or available for doing or making something. People, land, animals, money, skillsm and plants are resources that can be used for improving health.

An apparatus to produce artifical respiration (breathing). Respirators have very small pores (too small to see with the naked eye) that allow the wearer to breathe but prevent infectious agents from passing through.
Person who answers the questions in a questionnaire/survey.

A complex layer of tissue at the back of the eye, where the image from the light entering the eye is focused. When light hits the retina, it send signals to the brain along the optic nerve. The brain interprets these signals and turns them into information about what the eye is seeing.
A type of virus that must use reverse transcriptase to copy itself.
Using something more than once.
The likelihood or probability of the hazard occurring and the magnitude of the resulting effects. Danger.

The most common cause of severe diarrhoea in infants and young children. Nearly every child in the world has been infected with rotavirus at least once by the age of five.[2] Immunity develops with each infection, so subsequent infections are less severe; adults are rarely affected
In the water cycle; runoff includes all water that flows, under the force of gravity, across land in streams and rivers and across the surface, for example, of a field.
The triangular bone that forms the back of the pelvis.
Free from risk or danger, providing security or protection.
Watery fluid, secreted into the mouth by the salivary glands, that functions in the tasting, chewing, and swallowing of food, moistens the mouth, and starts the digestion of starches.
Sodium chloride, obtained from mines or by evaporation of sea water, used to flavour and preserve food.
The addition of salt (sodium chloride or NaCl) to food for the purpose of preservation.
A small part of anything intended to show the quality, style, or nature of the whole specimen. E.g. To study a sample of a population.
The process of selecting a number of study subjects from a defined study population (i.e. the population being investigated).
Public cleanliness involving community efforts in disease prevention, promoting hygiene, and keeping public places free of waste.

A parasite infestation of the skin caused by microscopic mites, Sarcoptes scabiei. These tiny animals are spread principally by direct skin-to-skin contact (e.g. during close physical contact between children and parents, or during sexual intercource), and to a lesser extent through contact with infested clothes and bedding.
A mark left by a healed wound, sore, or burn.

A severe, chronic mental illness, characterized by some, but not necessarily all, of the following features: emotional blunting, intellectual deterioration, social isolation, disorganized speech and behavior, delusions, and hallucinations.
A tough, leather-like, white tissue that extends all around the eye. Similar to an eggshell surrounding an egg and giving its shape, the sclera surrounds the eye and gives the eye its shape.
The detection of an infection in an individual who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease.
A disease caused by vitamin C deficiency which leads to sore skin, bleeding gums and internal bleeding.
The settling out of comparatively heavy suspended material (suspended solids) in water because of gravity.

Consist of fine particles of mostly inorganic material such as mud and salt washed into a stream as a result of land cultivation and construction. They may also arise from demolition and mining operations where these activities take place.
Division into segments.
A seizure or fit is caused by a sudden burst of excess electrical activity in the brain, causing a temporary disruption in the normal messages passing between brain cells.
The part of intrapersonal communication that determines how a person sees him or herself and how they are oriented toward others.

The most important predisposing factor for self-regulating one's behaviour is seen to be self-efficacy, that is the person's perception of how successful he or she can be in performing a particular behaviour.
Limiting oneself or itself.
Used for or capable of controlling or adjusting itself or oneself.
Self-treatment describes how the person with an illness does things (or takes medication) to try to help themselves.
An infection of the blood-sometimes called 'blood poisoning'.
The science dealing with the immunological properties and actions of serum.
The mixture of human waste with wastewater.
The biological characteristic that defines humans as female or male.
An acute intestinal infection caused by the bacterium Shigella, common among children and characterized by fever, abdominal pain and diarrhoea.
A dangerous condition with severe weakness or unconsciousness, cold sweat, and fast, weak pulse. It is caused by dehydration, hemorrhage, injury, burns, or severe illness.

In the last few days of pregnancy, the cervix may begin to open. Sometimes the mucus and a little bit of blood called 'show' drip out of the vagina. It may come out all at once, like a plug, or it may leak slowly for several days. When you see the show, you know that the cervix is softening.
Problems caused by using a medicine.

Signs of a disease are the features that would only be detected by a trained health worker (e.g. high temperature, fast pulse rate, enlargement of organs in the abdomen,etc.) to see what sickness the patient has.
Sino-implant is a contraceptive implant of two rods prepared from progestin, and is similar to Jadelle. It is effective for five years.
Sinuses are hollows in the bone that open into the nose. Sinusitis is inflammation causing pain above and below the eyes.
A small quantity of something spread thinly on a slide for microscopic examination.
"Smear-negative test" means a test that produced negative results and the test itself was based on a smear.
"Smear-positive test" means a test that produced positive results and the test itself was based on a smear.
Severe mental illness (SMI) are the more extreme and distressing disorders . Individuals with SMI are those with an illness that severely restricts their day-to-day activities.
Smoking is one of the oldest methods used to improve the quality of food and is commonly used to preserve meat and fish.
This is when mental or social distress (e.g. chronic poverty, marital problems) comes out as a physical symptom.
A sudden muscle contraction that a person cannot control.

Chemical barriers, or sperm-killing substances, available as foams, creams, gels, films or suppositories, which are often used in female contraception in conjunction with mechanical barriers and other devices. Spermicides are usually available without a prescription or medical examination.
A thin piece of wood or other rigid material used to immobilize a fractured or dislocated bone, or to maintain any part of the body in a fixed position.
To secure, hold in position, or support by means of a splint or splints, as a fractured bone. Splinting prevents further damage, which may result in loss of the limb or disability at a later period.
A jelly-like mucus coughed up from the lungs and bronchi of a sick person.
A person or group that has a shared interest in something.
(1) Completely clean and free from living micro-organisms. Things are usually sterilized by boiling or heating. (2) Sterile also means permanently unable to have children.
(1) To sterilize instruments, bottles, and other things by boiling or heating in an oven. (2) Permanent way of making a man or a woman unable to reproduce (have children).

Refers to the way in which a characteristic, marks the person out as different and leads to negative attitudes by others. E.g. Stigmatised People Living with HIV often feel isolated, abused and discriminated against by others.
Babies born dead after the 28th week of gestation.

Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is a term used to describe more than 20 different infections that are transmitted mainly through sexual contact via the exchange of semen, vaginal fluid, blood and other fluids; or by direct contact with the affected body areas of people with STIs.
A plan or method for obtaining a specific goal or result.
A harsh noise made during inhalation.
A sudden loss of consciousness, feeling, or ability to move, caused by bleeding or a clot inside the brain.

Chronic malnutrition in children.Stunting is defined as a low height for age of the child compared to the standard child of the same age. Stunted children have poor physical and intellectual performance and lower work output.
The vaccine is injected into the fatty tissue below the skin and above the muscle.
Using a device called a bulb syringe to extract mucus and fluid from the baby's nose and mouth.
A person who intends to purposefully kill themselves.
Also known as greywater, is water that has been used for washing in bathrooms and kitchens; it does not include human waste.
Above.
The upper part of a pit latrine, to provide protection from the rain and sun, and privacy and comfort for the user.
Supervision is usually a meeting at which you are able to sit down with a senior colleague and discuss issues that are important in your work.
A specially shaped capsule of medicine to put up the anus or vagina.
Able to be supported, maintained.
Sutures are joints between the bones of the skull. A suture is also a stitch made with needle and thread to sew up an opening or wound.
The feelings or conditions a person reports about his sickness.
A group of symptoms that patients describe, combined with classic signs that health workers observe during clinical assessment.
A chronic infectious disease, caused by bacteria called Treponema pallidum.
When we say that research has to be systematic, this means that a clear 'system' is used for collecting, recording, analysing and interpreting all the data.
Something that is avoided, banned, or not allowed because of a cultural belief.
Tapeworm infestation. Taeniasis is a parasitic zoonotic disease caused by the adult stage of large tapeworms that live in the intestines of human hosts.
Calculus of the teeth.
Tuberculosis (TB) is a disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It usually attacks the lungs, but can also affect other parts of the body.

Tetanus is a neurological disorder, that is, a disorder of the nervous system. Symptoms of tetanus are tight muscles that are difficult to relax, and muscle spasms (muscle contractions that occur without the person wanting them to).
An instrument used to measure how hot a person's body temperature is.
A crawling insect-like animal that buries its head under the skin and sucks blood.
The power of enduring or resisting the action of a drug, poison, etc. E.g. A tolerance to antibiotics.
Small organs in the throat, containing white blood cells, which help to prevent infection entering the body through the mouth.
Poison
Any poison produced by an organism.

Toxin rendered nontoxic by treatment with chemical agents or by physical means and used for administration into the body in order to produce specific immunity by stimulating the production of antibodies.
An infectious eye disease that can eventually cause blindness if left untreated.
A system of body organs and parts that work together to do a special job; for example, the urinary tract cleans the blood and gets rid of urine.
Traditions are long-established patterns of beliefs, actions or behaviours, often handed down within a community over many generations.
The act of being prepared for something, of being taught or learning a particular skill and practising it.
The release of water vapour (water as a gas) from plants and soils into the atmosphere.
Injury.
Managing in the application of medicines or other in order to relieve or cure an illness.
Involuntary shaking of the body or limbs.
Situations over a period of time.
Identifying the appropriate treatment according to the priority or severity of the symptoms.
Three month period.
In human fertilisation, it forms early embryo, fetal membranes and placenta after five to seven days.
A chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
A lump of new cells growing in an inappropriate location.
Thick or dense.
